stem: A 54-year-old man with systemic small-vessel vasculitis develops right hand grip weakness (3/5). Which deficit most specifically localizes an anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) palsy in this context?

choices.A: Inability to make a firm 'OK' sign due to flexor pollicis longus weakness
choices.C: Weakness of extensor carpi radialis brevis
choices.E: Pronator teres weakness with pain on resisted pronation

rationale_correct: AIN (median) innervates FPL and radial FDP; failure of the precision 'OK' pinch is classic for AIN neuropathy.

rationale_distractors.B: FCU is innervated by the ulnar nerve, not the AIN.
rationale_distractors.C: ECRB is radial (posterior compartment); AIN does not affect wrist extension.
rationale_distractors.D: ADM is ulnar nerve; its atrophy indicates ulnar neuropathy.
rationale_distractors.E: Pronator teres is median nerve but proximal (not AIN-specific).
